projecttitle: Soutenir la lutte contre les coronavirus (COVID-19) dans les communautés rurales et autochtones/Supporting Coronavirus (COVID-19) Response in Rural and Indigenous Communities
project_descrip: Short: SOUTENIR LA LUTTE CONTRE LES CORONAVIRUS (COVID-19) DANS LES COMMUNAUTÉS RURALES ET AUTOCHTONES/SUPPORTING CORONAVIRUS (COVID-19) RESPONSE IN RURAL AN Long: The project aims to increase the resilience of local food systems against the food, health, and economic impacts of coronavirus (COVID-19) for women, men and youth in vulnerable rural and Indigenous communities in Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua.  SeedChange and its local partners aim to work through community organizations, including community-based farmer research committees, cooperatives, local groups, and large NGOs, including CARE-Honduras, to support the poorest and most marginalized communities in delivering immediate assistance to reduce the emerging food crisis. Project activities include: (1) providing access to poor women and men smallholder farmers to seed reserves through existing community-based seedbanks (food-for-seed) and to quality, locally-produced, agro-ecologically adapted and nutritious basic grain seeds, semi-permanent and permanent fruit trees, and other production assets (e.g. poultry, tools), (2) providing logistical and storage support to humanitarian assistance organizations and delivering emergency food aid to the most vulnerable and in need, particularly women, children, and Indigenous people, and (3) providing farm and community storage structures for grains and seed, small scale water harvesting for irrigation, small livestock and poultry, low/high tunnel greenhouses for vegetable production and vegetable propagation for food insecure smallholder farmers, particularly women.  The project aims to reach 26,577 direct beneficiaries (at least half of which are expected to be women and girls) and 29,000 indirect beneficiaries. / Ce projet vise à accroître la résilience des systèmes alimentaires locaux pour atténuer les incidences alimentaires, sanitaires et économiques du coronavirus (COVID-19) sur les femmes, les hommes et les jeunes qui vivent dans des communautés rurales et autochtones vulnérables au Guatemala, au Honduras et au Nicaragua.  L'organisation Sème l'avenir et ses partenaires locaux visent à collaborer avec des organisations communautaires, dont des comités de chercheurs agricoles, des coopératives, des groupes locaux et d'importantes ONG, notamment CARE-Honduras, afin d'aider les collectivités les plus démunies et les plus vulnérables à fournir de l'aide immédiate pour atténuer la nouvelle crise alimentaire. Les activités du projet comprennent ce qui suit : 1) donner à de petits exploitants agricoles démunis (hommes et femmes) un accès à des réserves de semences par l'intermédiaire de banques de semences communautaires existantes (vivres contre semences), et leur donner un accès à des graines de céréales de qualité, nutritives, produites localement et adaptées à l'agroécologie, à des arbres fruitiers semi-permanents et permanents et à d'autres ressources de production (p. ex. volailles, outils), 2) fournir du soutien en matière de logistique et de stockage à des organisations d'aide humanitaire, et acheminer une aide alimentaire d'urgence aux personnes les plus vulnérables et les plus dans le besoin,

projecttitle: Promoting an efficient ICT infrastructure for achieving the Bharat Nirman
project_descrip: Short: PROMOTING AN EFFICIENT ICT INFRASTRUCTURE FOR ACHIEVING THE BHARAT NIRMAN Long: In 2005, the Government of India announced a mega project aimed at strengthening the physical infrastructure in rural India, with emphasis on roads, housing, electrification, irrigation, drinking water and telephone connection. The target date for completion of the four-year project is March 2009. With less than two years to accomplish its objectives, however, the project risks missing deadlines, incurring cost overruns and being perceived as a failure. On the other hand, information and communication technologies (ICTs) could be harnessed to allow the panchayats to monitor the progress of the rollout of the Bharat Nirman.''This grant will allow Telecom Live to advocate for the strategic use of ICTs to add a knowledge layer to the Bharat Nirman program. It will do so by producing quarterly documentaries of two hours each for national television. The documentaries will feature actual progress of Bharat Nirman on the ground, highlighting success stories that can be replicated and adapted. At the same time, Telecom Live will publish monthly reports containing in-depth analysis of the problems and challenges encountered, and the way they were overcome. Throughout the monthly reports and documentaries, an advocacy campaign will be built up to promote the strategic use of ICTs in achieving the Bharat Nirman program.

projecttitle: Alleviating Poverty and Malnutrition in Agro-biodiversity Hotspots of India (CIFSRF)
project_descrip: Short: ALLEVIATING POVERTY AND MALNUTRITION IN AGRO-BIODIVERSITY HOTSPOTS OF INDIA (CIFSRF) Long: The Government of India estimates that approximately one-quarter of its population is poor, with the majority living in rural regions and dependent on dryland farming for a living. Although India has a rich heritage of genetic diversity - more than 30 different main crops are grown in 18 of India's 31 states - this diversity and local food security is being challenged on the one hand, by central policies promoting irrigated rice and wheat cultivation, and on the other, by weak local capability and patchy infrastructure. This project - supported by the Canadian International Food Security Research Fund (CIFSRF), a joint program of IDRC and the Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA) - seeks to address the contradiction between the prosperity of nature and the poverty of the people in three distinct agro-biodiversity hotspots in the states of Orissa, Tamil Nadu and Kerala. Researchers at the M.S Swaminathan Research Foundation, India, and the University of Alberta, Canada, will design and test interventions aimed at enhancing farm productivity and increasing food, nutrition and income security in three dryland test regions. Attention to gender equity, environmental health and sustainable energy will be built into the project.

projecttitle: Food and Livelihood Security in Punjab through Water, Energy and Agricultural Management
project_descrip: Short: FOOD AND LIVELIHOOD SECURITY IN PUNJAB THROUGH WATER, ENERGY AND AGRICULTURAL MANAGEMENT Long: Climate change poses a significant threat to agrarian societies in tropical regions. In Punjab, which produces more than half of India's annual food grain production, there is rising uncertainty in the timing of the rainy season. This - combined with large state subsidies for the use of electricity in irrigation - has prompted farmers to increase their reliance on water drawn from deep aquifers and pay scant attention to irrigation scheduling based on climate and meteorological information. The result is declining groundwater levels and, for low-income farmers without direct access to electricity, increased food insecurity.This project aims to engage farmers, corporations and the state agricultural extension program in making better use of meteorological information to optimize water and energy use, and reduce pressure on overexploited aquifers. While previous work has targeted higher income farmers, this work will focus on lower income groups.Researchers will assess the vulnerability of the food production system to water scarcity, use seasonal climate forecasts to guide irrigation scheduling, fertilizer application and crop choice, optimize the use of agricultural technology to improve water use efficiency, and make use of mobile phone technology to facilitate an exchange of information between farmers and planners. The project is expected to result in policy recommendations aimed at promoting sustainable resource management and facilitating access to resources by low-income farmers.

projecttitle: Conflicts Around Water Use in Rainfed Agriculture: Addressing the Cross-Sectoral Dimensions
project_descrip: Short: CONFLICTS AROUND WATER USE IN RAINFED AGRICULTURE: ADDRESSING THE CROSS-SECTORAL DIMENSIONS Long: In a context of increasing water scarcity, conflicts over access to water for agriculture cannot be divorced from inter-sectoral conflicts i.e., between access to drinking water and access to irrigation water. The existing legal framework in India, however, while multi-layered and conceptually sound, loses potency when different strands simultaneously come into play, resulting in competing needs and contestations. This is because it is largely constructed around a sectoral understanding of water, with separate consideration of surface and groundwater rights, as well as distinct regulation for irrigation and drinking water supplies. This proposal seeks to examine the Rajsamand Lake dispute, which has been under judicial proceedings for several years. Undertaking primary data collection from a range of stakeholders and using secondary material, this case study will be analysed to fill a key research gap, i.e., to unearth and highlight the kinds of problems, both theoretical and empirical, which arise when various water rights - in this case, between irrigation and drinking water - clash, and to accordingly make some relevant policy recommendations.

The existing legal framework in India, however, while multi-layered and conceptually sound, loses potency when different strands simultaneously come into play, resulting in competing needs and contestations. This is because it is largely constructed around a sectoral understanding of water, with separate consideration of surface and groundwater rights, as well as distinct regulation for irrigation and drinking water supplies. This proposal seeks to examine the Rajsamand Lake dispute, which has been under judicial proceedings for several years. Undertaking primary data collection from a range of stakeholders and using secondary material, this case study will be analysed to fill a key research gap, i.e., to unearth and highlight the kinds of problems, both theoretical and empirical, which arise when various water rights - in this case, between irrigation and drinking water - clash, and to accordingly make some relevant policy recommendations.

projecttitle: FS/ENERGY AGRICULTURAL PUMPING
project_descrip: Short: FS/ENERGY AGRICULTURAL PUMPING Long: PROJECT DESCRIPTION: 1.BACKGROUND   IN MANY PARTS OF INDIA, GROUNDWATER IS DEPLETING RAPIDLY AND REACHING CRITICAL LEVELS OF OVERDRAFT IN MANY AREAS.  THIS IS WORSENING THE ALREADY POOR LEVELS OF HYDRAULIC AND ENERGY EFFICIENCIES IN IRRIGATION AND THEREBY INCREASING NET ENERGY INPUT AGRICULTURE.  AS THE ENERGY PRODUCTION IN INDIA IS DOMINATED BY FOSSIL FUELS, THE CLIMATE IMPACTS OF INEFFICIENT WATER AND ENERGY USE ARE SIGNIFICANT. FURTHERMORE, AS THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR IS CURRENTLY BEING SUBSIDISED THROUGH REDUCED ELECTRICITY RATES, THE IMPACT OF THE INEFFICIENT ENERGY PUMPS ON THE UTILITY IS ENORMOUS, BASICALLY MAKING THEM BROKE. AS POLITICALLY IT IS VERY DIFFICULT TO INCREASE THE ELECTRICITY COST, THIS RESULTS IN A TOTAL IMPASSE FOR THE UTILITIES, THAT ARE FACING OVER 80 MILLION PUMPS INSTALLED THROUGHOUT INDIA.   ECONOLER INTERNATIONAL HAS INITIATED AND IMPLEMENTED OVER THE LAST FOUR YEARS (2002-2005) A LARGE DSM INITIATIVE FINANCED BY THE CANADIAN CLIMATE CHANGE DEVELOPMENT FUND (CCCDF). DURING THE COURSE OF THIS DSM PROJECT, ECONOLER INTERNATIONAL HAS DEVELOPED A VERY SUCCESSFUL APPROACH WITH THE SUPPORT OF AN INDIAN PARTNER, BASIX ( WWW.BASIX.COM ), TO DEVELOP AN INNOVATIVE APPROACH TO SOLVE THE CURRENT PROBLEM RELATED TO INEFFICIENCY AND SUBSIDISED ENERGY USERS THAT IS FACED THROUGHOUT INDIA. ONE OF THE FOCUSES OF THE PROJECT WAS INDEED THE DEVELOPMENT OF A COMMERCIALLY STRUCTURED APPROACH TO ADDRESS THE AGRICULTURAL PUMPING SECTOR. EVEN THOUGH ONLY 50 PUMPS WERE IMPLEMENTED UNDER THE DEVELOPED APPROACH (WHICH GENERATED BETWEEN 25% AND 49% OF ELECTRICITY SAVINGS), THE PROJECT HAS DEMONSTRATED THAT A MARKET BASED APPROACH, USING AGRICULTURAL STAKEHOLDERS, THE ELECTRICITY UTILITIES AND CARBON FINANCE, CAN BE DEVELOPED TO SOLVE THE CURRENT PROBLEMATIC.   IN MAY 2005 , THE PRINCIPAL ENERGY SECRETARY OF THE GOVERNMENT OF MADHYA PRADESH (MP), MR. RAKESH SAHNI, INDICATED THAT THE GOVERNMENT OF MADHYA PRADESH WAS VERY INTERESTED TO MAKE SPECIAL EFFORTS TO STRUCTURE THE REPLICATION OF THE AGRICULTURE MODULE DEVELOPED BY ECONOLER INTERNATIONAL IN MANY REGIONS OF MP. IN THIS REGARD, IN JULY 2005, THE WORLD BANK ORGANIZED A LARGE WORKSHOP GATHERING SEVERAL ENERGY, AGRICULTURE AND RURAL SECRETARIES OF FEW STATES INCLUDING MADHYA PRADESH, ANDHRA PRADESH, MAHAJAN, TEMUL NADU, AND KARALLA. THIS LEAD TO THE APPROVAL OF THE LAUNCHED OF A FIRST DEPLOYMENT PHASE OF THE PROPOSED APPROACHED IN MADYA PRADESH WHERE 50 000 PUMPS WOULD BE REPLACED   2. PRINCIPAL OBJECTIVE OF THE PROJECT   THE PRESENT PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON THE REALISATION OF A DETAILLED FEASIBILITY STUDY TO HELP PREPARE THE LAUNCH OF THE WORLD BANK FINANCED PROJECT FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF AN INITIAL 50 000 PUMPS REPLACEMENT IN MADYA PRADESH.   THE ACTIVITIES OF THE PROJECT WILL BE:   - ANALYSE THE STRUCTURE AND THE ORGANISATIONAL SET-UP NEEDED TO ACHIEVE THE TARGETED IMPLEMENTATION OF 50,000 PUMPS BASED ON THE SCHEME DEVELOPED IN THE EARLIER SMALL DEMONSTRATION PROJECT. - DEVELOP AND ASSESS THE STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIP WITH PUMPS MANUFACTURERS THAT WILL BE NEEDED FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF SUCH A WIDE SCALE PROJECT - ANALYSE THE SOCIAL MOBILISATION STRATEGY BASED ON POVERTY REDUCTION AND GENDER EQUALITY CRITERIA - ASSESS THE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT OF THE PROJECT AND ESPECIALLY FOR THE OLD DISMANTLED PUMPS AND THE POTENTIAL OF RECYCLING OF THE SPARE PARTS IN THE INDIAN MARKET - DEVELOP A METHODOLOGY AND A BUNDLING CONCEPT TO RAISE THE BUYERS OF CERS INTEREST TOWARDS THE PROJECT AND GET THE APPROVAL OF THE UNFCCC TO SECURE THE CARBON FINANCING COMPONENT OF THE PROJECT - SUPPORT THE WORLD BANK IN SOME OF ITS NEEDED ACTIVITIES FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF ITS PROJECT, MAKING SURE NOT TO INTERVENE IN ANY PART WHERE THIS COULD EXCLUDE ECONOLER INTERNATIONAL FROM BIDDING ON THE PROJECT. - INVESTIGATE FURTHERMORE THE POTENTIAL OF THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE APPROACHES IN OTHER STATES IN INDIA, BASED ON THE INTEREST OF THE WORLD BANK TO IMPLEMENT ITS UPCOMING PROJECTCOUNTRIES: SECTORS:

projecttitle: IS/Training for Irrigation Development
project_descrip: Short: IS/TRAINING FOR IRRIGATION DEVELOPMENT Long: Project Description: The Government of Chhattisagrh (India) has selected, through an international open bids, Hydrosult Inc. (Canada)for the provision of technical assistance and consulting services for the implementation of Chhattusgarh Irrigation Development Sector Project (CIDP)which is a seven years loan project of about US$ 66 million dollar jointly funded by the Government of India and the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The overall CIDP (main project) goal is to improve rural livelihood and reduce rural poverty through improved irrigation services delivery, enhnanced agriculture practices, develop water users associations (WUA) and farmers training (women and men),and strengthened water resources management to increase the productivity of irrigated agriculture. The main part of the project budget (loan) is allocated to infrastructure rehabilitation. The value of Hydrosult consulting services (which covers two packages of the technical assistance)is about three million and three hundreds and ninty thousands US dollars (3 390 000)which is around 3800 000 CAD. Chhattisgarh is a newly estblished state (2000). The Water Resources Developemnt (WRD)which is in charge of water resources management has limited capacity for planning, design and implementing irrigation projects. As a result the performance of irrigation sector is very low and the overall efficiency of irrigation systems is about 50% (the lowest in India).   The objective of the proposed project is to provide additional support to the main project (CIDP) for training WRD staff in irrigation project planning and management including method of the preparation of environmental management plan and EIA, social analysis and study and gender consideration in irrigation planning and using modern techniques and software for project design, in addition to developing and implementing training program for training Water User Associations board including men and women members in WUA management and gender issues in participatory irrigation management.Countries: India (100%)  Sectors: 014000 (100%)

projecttitle: 20+5 Integrated Health and Dev. Project
project_descrip: Short: 20+5 INTEGRATED HEALTH AND DEV. PROJECT Long: Project Description: 20+5 Integrated Health and Dev. Project   The Canadian organization, Sahakarini, continues its collaboration with the Charitable Community Development Organization  (CCDO) in its efforts to reduce poverty amongst the untouchables in 20 villages and 5 peri-urban areas in  the state of Andrha Pradesh.  CCDO's efforts focus on small  community organizations for leadership, education and advocacy complemented with health education and provision of water, all  focussed on women, girls and family (40%). Community strengthening is also fostered through basic education plus  vocational training (20%),  agriculture development of  wastelands, (30%) and  small business training and credit for income generation (10%).  Main results will be increased self reliance, improved health and economic  activity. Expected Impact: Population healthier, more resilient , making best choices for own health.  Women and girls exercising more independence and choice.Expected Outcomes: 1) Communities will increase leadership capacity and increasingly rely on local leaders including women as effective agents of change, 2)  healthier communities, 4)  more remunerative employment for youth and economic returns to the communities, 5)  improved agricultural production and prosperity for farmers. 6) CCDO is stronger in the planning and implementing of sustainable initiatives. Expected Outputs:  increased capacity  of CCDO's organization, 2) increased capacity of  community groups, 3) the provision of clean water for improved health and sanitation, 4) promotion of  health, and sanitation including  treatment of malaria, TB, STDs and HIV/AIDS, 5) promotion of women as groups,  in school,  in vocations, 6) instructing and supporting farmers in recovery of wastelands, effective water conservation and irrigation,  environmental practices, planting and management of appropriate kitchen and cash crops.Countries: India (100%)  Sectors: 031130 (30%), 012261 (20%), 014030 (20%), 015150 (20%), 011230 (10%)  Themes: Capacity Development, Gender Equality

projecttitle: Save a Family Plan - Program 2010-2015 / Save a Family Plan - Programme 2010-2015
project_descrip: Short: SAVE A FAMILY PLAN - PROGRAM 2010-2015 / SAVE A FAMILY PLAN - PROGRAMME 2010-2015 Long: The Sustainability through Participation, Empowerment and Decentralization (SPED) program supports 29 regionally based NGO partners in 12 States of India to implement approximately 3,000 village-level socio-economic development initiatives in 580 villages, reaching over 400,000 individuals. These initiatives target the most marginalized populations, including (but not limited to) the poor, women, minorities, and members of the lowest social castes. The program trains Community Facilitation Teams (CFTs) as they in turn train local communities to form Village Actions Teams (VATs) and undertake initiatives aimed at poverty alleviation. Areas of poverty reduction initiatives include off farm livelihoods, agriculture, watershed management and irrigation, basic and non-formal education, health and hygiene promotion, gender mainstreaming, environment protection, and human rights advocacy. / Le programme Â« Durabilité via la participation, l'autonomie et la décentralisation Â» appuie 29 ONG partenaires régionales dans 12 États de l'Inde dans la mise en oeuvre d'environ 3 000 initiatives communautaires de développement socio-économique dans 580 villages, bénéficiant plus de 400,000 personnes. Ces initiatives visent les populations les plus marginalisées, notamment les pauvres, les femmes, les minorités et les membres des castes sociales les plus inférieures. Le programme forme des équipes d'animation communautaire qui forment ensuite les communautés locales à former des équipes d'action villageoise qui entreprendront des projets qui visent la réduction de la pauvreté. Les champs d'activités des projets incluent notamment les activités hors ferme génératrices de revenu, l'agriculture, la gestion de bassins versants et l'irrigation, l'éducation de base et non formelle, la promotion de la santé et de l'hygiène, l'intégration de la dimension genre, la protection de l'environnement et le plaidoyer pour les droits humains.

projecttitle: Green Community Development in Sulawesi (Green PNPM) / Développement communautaire écologique à Sulawesi (projet écologique PNPM)
project_descrip: Short: PUBLIC SECTOR POLICY AND ADM. MANAGEMENT Long: This project represents CIDA's contribution to Indonesia's National Program for Community Empowerment in Rural Areas (Indonesian acronym: PNPM). PNPM is a Government of Indonesia program that awards small grants to communities to help them deal with local needs, such as roads, irrigation, water supply, latrines, schools, and health centres. CIDA's contribution to PNPM introduced natural resource and environmental management practices into the program and, hence, is known as 'Green PNPM'. The Green PNPM project helps communities understand the negative and long-term impact of their actions on the surrounding environment and natural resources. It teaches them how to develop and implement ecological or 'green' PNPM proposals. Examples of such projects include small-scale renewable energy production, land-use planning, land or forest rehabilitation, wildlife conservation, eco-tourism, and marketing non-timber forest products. The Green PNPM project is focussed in three provinces in Sulawesi.   Key results as of January 2009 include: Over 60 training programs have been delivered, reaching a total of 1,124 participants. As a result of these programs, community facilitators have acquired knowledge and skills in natural resource management, communities have improved their proposal writing skills, and local governments and community members are able to apply sound ecological principles in land-use planning. The approach used in CIDA's Green PNPM project has attracted additional funding from other countries. Green PNPM will be expanded to six additional provinces on the islands of Sumatra and Papua, using the Sulawesi model. / Grâce à ce projet, l'ACDI participe à la réalisation du Programme national d'autonomisation des collectivités rurales de l'Indonésie (acronyme indonésien : PNPM). Le PNPM est un programme du gouvernement de l'Indonésie qui permet de verser de petites subventions aux collectivités afin de les aider à répondre aux besoins locaux comme les routes, l'irrigation, l'approvisionnement en eau, les latrines, les écoles et les centres de santé. La contribution de l'ACDI au PNPM a permis d'intégrer des pratiques de gestion de l'environnement et des ressources naturelles au programme qui l'on connait sous le nom de « projet écologique PNPM ». Celui-ci aide les collectivités à comprendre comment leurs actions ont des répercussions négatives et durables sur les ressources naturelles et l'environnement avoisinants. Il permet aussi de leur apprendre à élaborer et à mettre en oeuvre des propositions écologiques dans le cadre du PNPM. De tels projets portent entre autres sur la production d'énergie renouvelable à petite échelle, l'aménagement du territoire, la remise en état des terres ou des forêts, la protection de la faune, l'écotourisme et les produits forestiers non ligneux pour le marketing. Le projet écologique PNPM cible trois provinces de Sulawesi.   En janvier 2009, les résultats suivants avaient été obtenus, entre autres : plus de 60 programmes de formation ont été mis en oeuvre auxquels ont participé 1 124 personnes. Grâce à ces programmes, les animateurs des collectivités ont acquis des connaissances et des compétences en gestion des ressources naturelles, les collectivités ont renforcé leur capacité de préparation de propositions, les autorités locales et les membres de la collectivité ont mis en pratique de principes écologiques et sains d'aménagement du territoire. L'approche utilisée dans le projet écologique PNPM de l'ACDI a permis d'obtenir du financement supplémentaire d'autres pays. Le projet écologique PNPM sera élargi pour inclure six autres provinces des îles de Sumatra et de la Papouasie, selon le modèle de Sulawesi.

The approach used in CIDA's Green PNPM project has attracted additional funding from other countries. Green PNPM will be expanded to six additional provinces on the islands of Sumatra and Papua, using the Sulawesi model. / Grâce à ce projet, l'ACDI participe à la réalisation du Programme national d'autonomisation des collectivités rurales de l'Indonésie (acronyme indonésien : PNPM). Le PNPM est un programme du gouvernement de l'Indonésie qui permet de verser de petites subventions aux collectivités afin de les aider à répondre aux besoins locaux comme les routes, l'irrigation, l'approvisionnement en eau, les latrines, les écoles et les centres de santé. La contribution de l'ACDI au PNPM a permis d'intégrer des pratiques de gestion de l'environnement et des ressources naturelles au programme qui l'on connait sous le nom de « projet écologique PNPM ». Celui-ci aide les collectivités à comprendre comment leurs actions ont des répercussions négatives et durables sur les ressources naturelles et l'environnement avoisinants. Il permet aussi de leur apprendre à élaborer et à mettre en oeuvre des propositions écologiques dans le cadre du PNPM. De tels projets portent entre autres sur la production d'énergie renouvelable à petite échelle, l'aménagement du territoire, la remise en état des terres ou des forêts, la protection de la faune, l'écotourisme et les produits forestiers non ligneux pour le marketing. Le projet écologique PNPM cible trois provinces de Sulawesi.   En janvier 2009, les résultats suivants avaient été obtenus, entre autres : plus de 60 programmes de formation ont été mis en oeuvre auxquels ont participé 1 124 personnes. Grâce à ces programmes, les animateurs des collectivités ont acquis des connaissances et des compétences en gestion des ressources naturelles, les collectivités ont renforcé leur capacité de préparation de propositions, les autorités locales et les membres de la collectivité ont mis en pratique de principes écologiques et sains d'aménagement du territoire. L'approche utilisée dans le projet écologique PNPM de l'ACDI a permis d'obtenir du financement supplémentaire d'autres pays. Le projet écologique PNPM sera élargi pour inclure six autres provinces des îles de Sumatra et de la Papouasie, selon le modèle de Sulawesi.

projecttitle: Multidonor Trust Fund - Phase II - Tsunami / Fonds fiduciaire multidonateurs - phase II - tsunami
project_descrip: Short: MULTIDONOR TRUST FUND - PHASE II - TSUNAMI / FONDS FIDUCIAIRE MULTIDONATEURS - PHASE II - TSUNAMI Long: The Mulitdonor Trust Fund, developed at the request of the Government of Indonesia, enables different donors to pool their resources and coordinate their assistance. The fund finances new and ongoing rehabilitation and reconstruction projects, as well as strengthening the capacity of national and local governments and civil society organizations. As part of this fund, 17 sub-projects have been approved in the areas of infrastructure and community recovery, capacity rebuilding, sustainable management of the environment, and livelihoods recovery. Phase II builds on the success of the first phase of the fund. Results as of February 2009 include: 6,554 houses have been built, with an 86% occupancy rate, and 6,911 houses have been rehabilitated, with a 100% occupancy rate. In addition, 1,450 houses are under construction in Aceh and 1,998 in Nias. 2,585 km of roads and 932 bridges have been built or repaired, 1,211 irrigation/drainage units have been provided, and 1,408 clean water projects were supported. 20 village markets, 275 school buildings, 19 health clinics or posts, 684 waste disposal facilities, and 120 village halls have been built or repaired. Individual microcredit grants were provided to 6,693 women and 5,425 men, enabling them to regain their livelihoods and thereby contributing to economic recovery in tsunami-affected regions. A number of grants were also allocated to communities, most of which supported infrastructure and transport recovery, as well as governance and environmental sustainability. / Le Fonds fiduciaire multidonateurs, établi à la demande du gouvernement de l'Indonésie, permet à divers donateurs de regrouper leurs ressources et de coordonner leur aide. Ce fonds contribue au financement de projets - nouveaux et en cours - de relèvement et de reconstruction, ainsi qu'au renforcement des capacités du gouvernement national, des administrations locales et d'organismes de la société civile. Grâce à ce fonds, 17 sous-projets ont été approuvés dans les secteurs du rétablissement des communautés, de l'infrastructure, des capacités et des moyens de subsistance ainsi qu'au niveau de la gestion durable de l'environnement. La phase II poursuit le travail de la première phase du fonds, qui a connu du succès. Résultats en février 2009 : Le taux d'occupation de 6 554 maisons est de 86 p. 100 et 6 911 maisons, qui sont toutes habitées, ont été remises en état. En outre, 1 450 maisons sont en cours de construction à Aceh et 1 998 à Nias. projecttitle: Improving Solid Waste Management and Income Creation in Host Communities / Améliorer la gestion des déchets solides et générer des revenus dans les co
project_descrip: Short: IMPROVING SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT AND INCOME CREATION IN HOST COMMUNITIES / AMÉLIORER LA GESTION DES DÉCHETS SOLIDES ET GÉNÉRER DES REVENUS DANS LES CO Long: This project aims to mitigate an environmental disaster in Jordan's Northern Governorate of Irbid, restore confidence in municipal services and ease social burdens in refugee-hosting communities. As a result of the Syrian crisis, host communities in Jordan's northern governorate Irbid have seen a significant increase in residents. Consequently, the amount of solid waste deposited on the Alakedir landfill now exceeds the absorptive capacity of the site and is leading towards the contamination of soil and ground-water resources. The project supports Jordan's efforts to improve its solid waste management infrastructure and services, improve health conditions of landfill staff and local communities, and create income generating activities through innovative economic growth programs.   Some project activities include: (1) rehabilitating landfill infrastructure (roads, irrigation, maintenance, and design and excavation of an additional 300,000 cubic metre landfill cells) to adequately accommodate the amounts and types of waste at the Alakedir site, (2) designing, constructing and equipping two transfer stations and a solid waste segregation and recycling unit to assist in the management of waste before final disposal at the site, (3) developing and delivering training courses for 100 municipal managers and landfill employees in integrated solid waste management and relevant skills, and (4) providing support for the establishment of a cooperative society for recycling and marketable products to increase the economic benefits of the site for local communities. / Ce projet vise à atténuer une catastrophe environnementale dans le gouvernorat Nord d'Irbid, en Jordanie, à rétablir la confiance de la population à l'égard des services publics et à alléger le fardeau social dans les collectivités qui accueillent des réfugiés. En raison de la crise en Syrie, les collectivités d'accueil du gouvernorat Nord d'Irbid, en Jordanie, affichent une hausse considérable du nombre de résidants. C'est pourquoi la quantité de déchets solides déposés dans le site d'enfouissement d'Alakedir dépasse maintenant la capacité d'absorption du site, ce qui entraine la pollution des ressources en sol et en eau souterraine. Le projet appuie les efforts de la Jordanie afin d'améliorer ses infrastructures et ses services de gestion des déchets solides ainsi que les conditions de santé du personnel des sites d'enfouissement et des collectivités locales et de mettre en oeuvre des activités rémunératrices au moyen de programmes novateurs liés à la croissance économique.   Parmi les activités du projet : 1) remettre en état les infrastructures des sites d'enfouissement (routes, canaux d'irrigation, entretien ainsi que conception et excavation de 300 000 mètres cubes de plus de cellules d'enfouissement) pour recevoir adéquatement la quantité et les types de déchets dans le site d'Alakedir, 2) concevoir et construire deux centres de transfert et une unité de triage des déchets solides et de re

projecttitle: Nour: Enhancing Child Protection, Education and Economic Resilience in Jordan / Améliorer la protection des enfants, l'éducation et la résilience écon
project_descrip: Short: NOUR: ENHANCING CHILD PROTECTION, EDUCATION AND ECONOMIC RESILIENCE IN JORDAN / AMÉLIORER LA PROTECTION DES ENFANTS, L'ÉDUCATION ET LA RÉSILIENCE ÉCON Long: This project seeks to address key challenges affecting children's safety and education in Jordan. The project aims is to ensure Jordanian and Syrian girls and boys and their families have access to quality child protection, early childhood, and primary education services.   Project activities include: (1) establish early childhood care and development centers, rehabilitate 20 public schools and train teachers and school staff on positive discipline and child-centred teaching methods, (2) rehabilitate municipal offices providing child protection services and public play areas and train local government representatives and ministry staff on gender-sensitive child protection services, and (3) pilot an innovative approach to prevent the adoption of negative coping mechanisms affecting children's safety and education by introducing cost-saving renewable and energy-efficient technologies for poor households. / Le présent projet cherche à répondre aux principaux problèmes touchant la sécurité et l'éducation des enfants en Jordanie. Il veille à ce que les filles et les garçons de Jordanie et de Syrie, ainsi que leur famille, aient accès à des services de qualité en matière de protection de l'enfance, de la petite enfance et de l'enseignement primaire.   Les activités du projet comprennent : 1) l'établissement de centres de soin de la petite enfance et de développement, la remise en état de 20 écoles publiques ainsi que la formation d'enseignants et de personnel sur les mesures disciplinaires positives et les méthodes d'enseignement axées sur l'enfant, 2) la remise en état de bureaux municipaux offrant des services de protection de l'enfance ainsi que d'espaces de jeu publics et la formation de représentants locaux du gouvernement ainsi que d'employés du ministère sur les services de protection de l'enfance qui tiennent compte des séxospécificités, 3) la mise à l'essai d'une démarche novatrice visant à prévenir l'adoption de mécanismes d'adaptation négatifs ayant des incidences sur la sécurité et l'éducation des enfants, en proposant des technologies renouvelables et éco-énergétiques économiques pour les ménages pauvres.

projecttitle: Enhancing Child Protection, Education and Economic Resilience in Jordan/Améliorer la protection des enfants, l'éducation et la résilience économique en Jordanie
project_descrip: Short: ENHANCING CHILD PROTECTION, EDUCATION AND ECONOMIC RESILIENCE IN JORDAN/AMÉLIORER LA PROTECTION DES ENFANTS, L'ÉDUCATION ET LA RÉSILIENCE ÉCONOMIQUE E Long: This project aims to improved resilience and well-being of Syrian refugees and host communities in four governorates in Jordan (Irbid, Mafraq, Amman and Zarqa). To do so, the project seeks to improve girl's and boy's education outcomes, strengthen child protection and enhance the economic resilience of refugee and host community families. Project activities include: (1) increasing knowledge of teachers in child-friendly methodologies and child rights, (2) increasing access to safe opportunities within communities for gender responsive development and psychosocial support for girls and boys, and (3) increasing household savings (on energy and water) through adoption on renewable energy and resources./Ce projet vise à améliorer la résilience et le bien-être des refugiés syriens et des collectivités d'accueil dans quatre gouvernorats de la Jordanie (Irbid, Mafraq, Amman et Zarqa). Pour ce faire, le projet cherche à améliorer les résultats en matière d'éducation pour les filles et les garçons à renforcer la protection des enfants et à améliorer la résilience économique des familles de réfugiés et des collectivités d'accueil. Parmi les activités du projet : 1) amélioration des connaissances des enseignants au sujet des méthodes adaptées aux enfants et aux droits de l'enfant, 2) élargissement de l'accès à des possibilités sécuritaires au sein des collectivités pour un développement sexospécifique et un soutien psychosocial pour les filles et les garçons, 3) accroissement des économies des ménages (en énergie et en eau) grâce à l'utilisation de l'énergie et de ressources renouvelables.

projecttitle: Lake Naivasha Sustainability : Ecosystem Improvement for Health and Wellbeing
project_descrip: Short: LAKE NAIVASHA SUSTAINABILITY : ECOSYSTEM IMPROVEMENT FOR HEALTH AND WELLBEING Long: Lake Naivasha basin located in the Great Rift Valley in Kenya is the site of increasing economic activity, especially floriculture. The floriculture industry provides economic benefits but increases the demand on ecosystem services. The industry and associated settlements depend on lake water for geothermal energy, household water supplies, irrigation, discharge and fishing. At the same time, the basin is being affected by climate change. This project seeks to obtain a better understanding of watershed hydrology, chemical pollution and health conditions among residents and floriculture workers, including those related to chemical exposure and other environmental hazards. The overall goal is to make recommendations for the sustainable management of natural resources in the basin to the benefit of both ecosystem and human health and wellbeing.

projecttitle: Integrating Indigenous Knowledge in Climate Risk Management to Support Community Based Adaptation
project_descrip: Short: INTEGRATING INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGE IN CLIMATE RISK MANAGEMENT TO SUPPORT COMMUNITY BASED ADAPTATION Long: Traditionally, African farmers have used indigenous knowledge to understand weather and climate patterns and make decisions about crop and irrigation cycles. However, increased variability associated with climate change has reduced their confidence in traditional knowledge. Scientific weather forecasts, on the other hand, are formulated on a much larger scale and are presented in a manner unfamiliar to farmers. This creates a dilemma for those who recognize the limitations of traditional climate forecasts but are unable to use scientific ones. To address this problem, researchers will endeavor to integrate indigenous knowledge into scientific climate forecasts at the local level, where it can be used to enhance the resilience of communities vulnerable to climate change. The project will be carried out in Nganyi community in western Kenya, an area that is known to have a well-established system of traditional weather forecasting.

projecttitle: Promoting Greater Community Benefit and Accountability in Large Scale Land Acquisitions in Kenya
project_descrip: Short: PROMOTING GREATER COMMUNITY BENEFIT AND ACCOUNTABILITY IN LARGE SCALE LAND ACQUISITIONS IN KENYA Long: At the core of Vision 2030, the Kenyan government's main development plan, is the effective development of land.  Agriculture, natural resource exploitation, and infrastructure development will be key vehicles to achieve this objective. Delivering on the promise of this vision will depend on the extent to which the government manages to implement transparent and accountable processes of large-scale land acquisition that safeguard and do not disadvantage local communities. In a context marked by high levels of poverty, and unclear or insecure land tenure rights, the mainly rural population might be vulnerable to inequitable treatment during land acquisitions, as well as to exposure to negative impacts if social and environmental safeguards are not followed. The aim of this project is to explore the most effective ways of ensuring the accountability of government managed processes to protect the interests of vulnerable communities in circumstances of large scale land acquisitions. To that end, the project proposes to review current policy and legislative criteria, particularly those developed under Kenya's 2010 Constitution, for the acquisition and granting of land for investment purposes in Kenya. Complementing this analysis, the project will develop a community based scorecard to track the impact and implementation on the ground in concrete communities of pre-existing and newly developed laws. Findings will then be used as a barometer to assess the legitimacy and accountability of processes governing large-scale land acquisitions, along with interviews with public officials, investors and other relevant stakeholders. Data generated by this project will ultimately help inform future legislation and policy, and act as a vehicle to engage a broader range of stakeholders in government and private sector. The research will target two regions in Kenya. In Siaya county, where a 25-year lease was granted to a private company over the expansive Yala Swamp to undertake large scale irrigation farming. The second set of sites will be Lamu and Isiolo counties, which are at the centre of implementation a planned new port at Lamu through Kenya to Ethiopia and South Sudan. This project is being developed as part of a cohort of planned projects on promoting accountability around large-scale land acquisitions in Africa.

projecttitle: Improving Agricultural Productivity and Resilience with Satellite and Cellphone Imagery to Scale Climate-Smart Crop Insurance (Cultiaf-2)
project_descrip: Short: IMPROVING AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTIVITY AND RESILIENCE WITH SATELLITE AND CELLPHONE IMAGERY TO SCALE CLIMATE-SMART CROP INSURANCE (CULTIAF-2) Long: The livelihoods of millions of smallholder farmers across the developing world are under threat from extreme weather events such as droughts, floods, and heatwaves. Risks are projected to increase significantly in future years due to climate change and the anticipation of possible losses discourages farmers from making productivity-enhancing investments, thereby trapping them in low-risk, low-return agriculture. Agricultural insurance, complemented with other risk-reducing practices, can be a sustainable approach to unlock investments in agriculture for smallholders that improve their resilience and productivity. Crop insurance protects farmers against financial risks posed by extreme weather events and has been widely advocated as a tool to help farmer households escape poverty traps and invest in climate-smart high-productivity agriculture. The number of successful insurance schemes targeting smallholders is limited due to high monitoring and verification costs of traditional insurance, low demand for index-based insurance (designed to eliminate the need to verify losses) mainly due to poor trust and basis risks (i.e. the imperfect correlation between farmers' actual losses and insurance payouts), and the fact that insurance products often neglect complementary risk-management options such as irrigation and drought-tolerant cultivars. This project aims to overcome these problems through climate-smart picture-based insurance, which uses satellite and cellphone imagery to verify losses, observe management practices, and promote the adoption of productivity-enhancing and resilient technologies through advisories and bundling. Ground pictures taken by farmers will help reduce monitoring costs, minimize basis risks, and create synergies with climate-smart resilience technologies. By taking pictures of insured crops, farmers engage directly in the insurance process and improve trust and tangibility. The project will compare the picture and satellite-based insurance with the current area and yield-based insurance and it will assess the effectiveness of increasing the productivity, resilience, and food security of women, men, and youth smallholder farmers in Kenya.  This project is funded through the second phase of the Cultivate Africa's Future Fund (CultiAF-2), a joint program of IDRC and the Australian International Food Security Research Centre of the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. CultiAF supports research to achieve long-term food security in eastern and southern Africa.

projecttitle: Support to Lao National Unexploded Ordnance Programme
project_descrip: Short: SUPPORT TO LAO NATIONAL UNEXPLODED ORDNANCE PROGRAMME Long: During the Second Indochina war (1964-1975), more bombs (more than two million tonnes) were dropped on Lao PDR than on Japan and Germany combined during World War II, making Lao PDR the most heavily bombed country in the world. It is estimated that up to 30 per cent of these munitions failed to explode. Even today, they continue to threaten the lives and well-being of the Lao people. Cluster sub-munitions or â€˜bombies  are the most common form of unexploded ordnance (UXO) remaining. Consummate to the scale of the contamination, UXO presents a threat to human security and a hindrance to the country s socio-economic development. The worst impacted areas are poor, rural and remote. UXO needs to be cleared in order for socio-economic development to take place.Recognising the impact that UXO has on socio-economic development, the Government of Lao PDR (GoL) established the Lao National Unexploded Ordnance Programme (UXO Lao) with the support of UNDP, UNICEF, and other donors in 1996. UXO Lao is the national UXO clearance operator in Lao PDR. The organisation works in the nine most heavily UXO impacted provinces. UXO Lao clears land for agriculture, community purposes (e.g. schools, hospitals, temples, and water supply) and to support development activities. It also conducts risk-reduction education activities (Community Awareness or CA) in affected communities. UXO Lao operates under the generic principles of mine action: (1) conducting area clearance and roving clearance (emergency EOD tasks), (2) general and technical survey, and (3) UXO risk awareness activities.UXO Lao s activities contribute not only to saving the lives of the people living in areas of UXO contamination, but also to increasing socio-economic opportunities in some of the poorest districts. Besides areas cleared for agricultural land, UXO Lao also supports the Lao Government s development projects, as well as those of other international non-governmental organisations (INGO) to allow infrastructure development to occur, including the establishment of irrigation supplies, school constructions, hospitals, health centres, clean water projects, roads, and other development activities. EXPECTED RESULTSSupport for UXO Lao Survey and Clearance OperationsSurvey and clearance operations are the core of UXO Lao s activities and contribute to the overall reduction of risk to the population of Lao PDR.  The funding requested will fund survey and clearance activities that will be undertaken by UXO Lao during the course of the period. The funding will be part of a larger contribution from other donors, through the UNDP including Trust Fund and other funding sources, and also bilateral to UXO Lao. Current activities in Laos are expected to move toward a greater reliance on survey during the end of the year 2013, but both survey and clearance activities result in the same output - released and safe land.UXO Lao plans to clear or release 3,167 hectares of land in calendar year 2013. Extrapolating

projecttitle: Climate Knowledge Brokering in West Africa. A learning by doing approach
project_descrip: Short: CLIMATE KNOWLEDGE BROKERING IN WEST AFRICA. A LEARNING BY DOING APPROACH Long: Increasing resilience to climate change in West Africa is integral to enhancing food security. This calls for more sustainably and efficiently managing water resources for agriculture. This is particularly critical in Burkina Faso, Mali, and Niger, where the population is still largely based in rural areas and will continue to be in the next 10-20 years, despite increasing urbanization. There is a need to connect the results of innovative and applied research to climate action that reduces smallholder vulnerabilities.This project aims to contribute to increased climate resilience and enhanced food security in the Sahel by supporting the dissemination and scaling up of two effective adaptation options:  supplementary irrigation systems and access to climate information for smallholder farmers. The partner, PROCASUR (a non-governmental organization for regional capacity building in rural development), will test a hands-on approach to climate knowledge brokering for the dissemination and scaling up of adaptation and agricultural resilience projects in rural West Africa. The approach involves working in support of another IDRC-funded project in sustainable management of water catchment basins for irrigation in Burkina Faso, Mali, and Niger to strengthen its research-into-use strategy and activities. Innovative methodologies developed and tested widely by PROCASUR will be tailored to respond to identified challenges and barriers to successful scaling of adaptation technologies and to engage key stakeholders in a process of shared learning.

projecttitle: Rehabililtation of Agricultural Irrigation Infrastructures in the Zone of the Office du Niger / Réhabilitation d'infrastructures hydro-agricoles dans la zone de l'Office du Niger
project_descrip: Short: AGRICULTURAL SERVICES Long: In order to help Mali feed its ever-growing population, this project is helping to develop and rehabilitate the agricultural irrigation infrastructure in the zone of the Office du Niger. This support is expected to contribute to increasing Mali's agricultural production to 10 million tons of cereal per year by 2012. L'Office du Niger is the organization responsible for promoting the development of Mali's rice production in the Ségou region. It has put in place a massive gravitation irrigation system capable of serving 960,000 ha, 85,000 ha of which have been developed and are being exploited. / En regard des besoins du Mali pour nourrir une population sans cesse croissante, le projet vient en aide au niveau de la réhabilitation et du développement des infrastructures hydro-agricoles dans la zone de l'Office du Niger. Les résultats attendus à terme sont une augmentation de la production agricole au Mali de façon à atteindre 10 millions de tonnes de céréales par an à l'horizon 2012. L'Office du Niger est l'organisme responsable de la mise en valeur des potentialités de culture rizicole au Mali dans la région de Ségou. Il a mis en place un vaste réseau d'irrigation gravitaire desservant quelques 960 000 ha dont environ 85 000 ha sont aménagés et actuellement exploités.

project_descrip: Short: STRENGTHENING IRRIGATED AGRICULTURE IN MALI PROJECT (REAGIR) / PROJET DE RENFORCEMENT DE L AGRICULTURE IRRIGUÉE AU MALI (REAGIR) Long: The Strengthening Irrigated Agriculture in Mali project (REAGIR) aims to sustainably develop irrigated agriculture in Mali to increase food security through increased agricultural production, mainly in the regions of Mopti and Koulikoro. The resources allocated for the REAGIR project make it possible to construct and rehabilitate productive infrastructure, such as irrigated fields, micro dams, warehouses and rural roads, coach and train agricultural producers to support increased productivity and the development of knowledge and tools, and protect and improve sustainable development of natural resources, specifically soil and water. The initiative contributea to the implementation of the German small-scale irrigation program and will be integrated into the implementation of the National Small-Scale Irrigation Program in Mali. / Le Projet de renforcement de l agriculture irriguée au Mali (REAGIR) vise la poursuite du développement durable de l agriculture irriguée afin d accroître la sécurité alimentaire à travers l augmentation de la production agricole, principalement dans les régions de Mopti et Koulikoro. Les principales activités portent sur l aménagement, la construction et la réhabilitation d infrastructures liés à la production, la conservation et la commercialisation (périmètres irrigués villageois, micro-barrages, magasins de stockage et pistes rurales) des produits agricoles issus de l irrigation. De l accompagnement et de la formation des producteurs et productrices à de nouvelles techniques agricoles et sur l utilisation durable des ressources naturelles (sol et eau) sont aussi prévus. L initiative contribue à la mise en oeuvre de la programmation de la coopération allemande dans le secteur de l irrigation de proximité et par le fait même, s intègre dans la mise en oeuvre du Programme national d irrigation de proximité du Mali.

projecttitle: Food for Work and Promotion of Local Cereal Purchases / Vivres contre Travail et achats locaux de céréales (VITAL)
project_descrip: Short: FOOD FOR WORK AND PROMOTION OF LOCAL CEREAL PURCHASES / VIVRES CONTRE TRAVAIL ET ACHATS LOCAUX DE CÉRÉALES (VITAL) Long: This project is intended to increase the resilience of Malians to environmental and social shocks through targeted food security interventions in the Kayes, Koulikoro, Ségou and Mopti regions. This project is also aimed at strengthening national mechanisms for addressing food insecurity and proposing sustainable solutions through its support for the development of a national food security policy. The activities include 1) supporting the creation and rehabilitation of agricultural productive infrastructure through food assistance operations to create assets, 2) promoting local cereal purchases, and 3) improving the capacities of small-scale producers through the Purchase for Progress initiative. / Ce projet vise à accroitre la résilience des maliennes et des maliens aux chocs environnementaux et sociaux à travers des interventions ciblées en sécurité alimentaire dans les régions de Kayes, Koulikoro, Ségou et Mopti. Ce projet vise également à renforcer les dispositifs nationaux de lutte contre l'insécurité alimentaire et à proposer des solutions durables par son appui à l'élaboration de la politique nationale de sécurité alimentaire. Les activités comprennent : 1) appui à la création et à la réhabilitation d'infrastructures productives agricoles à travers des Activités d'Assistance Alimentaire pour la création d'actifs , 2) promotion des achats locaux de céréales, 3) amélioration des capacités des petits producteurs par l'initiative Achats pour le Progrès.

projecttitle: Mali - Emergency Response in Gao and Bourem - OXFAM-Québec Appeal 2014 / Mali - Réponse d urgence à Gao et Bourem - Appel d OXFAM-Québec 2014
project_descrip: Short: MALI - EMERGENCY RESPONSE IN GAO AND BOUREM - OXFAM-QUÉBEC APPEAL 2014 / MALI - RÉPONSE D URGENCE À GAO ET BOUREM - APPEL D OXFAM-QUÉBEC 2014 Long: March 2014 - Some 3.3 million people in Mali do not have access to sufficient, safe and nutritious food. Unrest and conflict in the north, have displaced 472,000 people, including 171,000 who have fled to neighbouring countries to escape the violence. Fighting, banditry and land-mine contamination restrict the access for relief agencies to only some areas, where basic services such as medical care and water and sanitation services are gradually resuming. Refugees, internally displaced persons, and host communities are in need of immediate humanitarian assistance, including protection, shelter, food, nutrition and livelihoods assistance, as well as access to clean water, health and sanitation services.   With DFATD s support, OXFAM-Québec is providing emergency assistance for 36,000 conflict-affected people in the districts of Gao and Bourem, including access to water, and the provision of essential items to improve their health and livelihoods. Project activities include: (1) rehabilitation or construction of water points for the supply of safe drinking water, (2) distribution of hygiene kits, including soap, jerry cans and mosquito nets , (3) distribution of seeds and tools to produce rice (4) rehabilitation of irrigated dikes to prevent flooding, and (5) promotion of human rights and equity in accessing humanitarian assistance. / Mars 2014 - Quelque 3,3 millions de personnes vivant au Mali n ont pas accès à une alimentation suffisante, saine et nutritive. Les troubles et le conflit qui touchent le Nord du pays ont entraîné le déplacement de 472 000 personnes, dont 171 000 qui ont dû fuir vers des pays voisins pour échapper à la violence. Les combats, le pillage et les terres contaminées par des mines terrestres restreignent l accès des organisations d aide à quelques régions seulement, oÃ¹ les services de base tels que les soins médicaux et les services d approvisionnement en eau et d assainissement reprennent peu à peu. Les réfugiés, les personnes déplacées à l intérieur de leur pays et les collectivités d accueil ont besoin d une aide humanitaire immédiate, ce qui comprend de la protection, des abris, des aliments, des services de nutrition et de l aide au rétablissement des moyens de subsistance, un accès à des services d approvisionnement en eau potable et d assainissement et des soins de santé.   Avec le soutien du MAECD, OXFAM-Québec fournit une aide d urgence à 36 000 personnes touchées par le conflit dans les districts de Gao et de Bourem, ce qui comprend un accès à de l eau et la fourniture d articles essentiels pour améliorer leur santé et leurs moyens de subsistance. Les activités de ce projet comprennent : 1) la remise en état ou la construction de points d eau pour l approvisionnement en eau potable, 2) la distribution de trousses d hygiène comprenant entre autres du savon, des bidons et des moustiquaires de protection contre les moustiques, 3) la distribution de semences et d outils pour la production de riz, 4) la remise en état

projecttitle: Rehabililtation of Agricultural Irrigation Infrastructures in the Zone of the Office du Niger/Réhabilitation des infrastructures hydro-agricoles dans la zone de l'Office du Niger
project_descrip: Short: REHABILILTATION OF AGRICULTURAL IRRIGATION INFRASTRUCTURES IN THE ZONE OF THE OFFICE DU NIGER/RÉHABILITATION DES INFRASTRUCTURES HYDRO-AGRICOLES DANS Long: This project contributes to developing and rehabilitating the agricultural irrigation infrastructure in the zone of the Office du Niger in order to increase Mali's agricultural production. L'Office du Niger is the organization responsible for promoting the development of Mali's rice production in the Ségou region. It has put in place a massive gravitation irrigation system capable of serving 960,000 ha, 85,000 ha of which have been developed and are being exploited./ Le projet appuie la réhabilitation et le développement des infrastructures hydro-agricoles dans la zone de l'Office du Niger afin d'augmenter la production agricole au Mali. L'Office du Niger est l'organisme responsable de la mise en valeur des potentialités de culture rizicole au Mali dans la région de Ségou. Il a mis en place un vaste réseau d'irrigation gravitaire desservant quelques 960 000 ha dont environ 85 000 ha sont aménagés et actuellement exploités.

projecttitle: Strengthening the Nutritional Resilience and Food Security of the Most Vulnerable in Mali/Renforcer la résilience nutritionnelle et la sécurité alimentaire des plus vulnérables au Mali
project_descrip: Short: STRENGTHENING THE NUTRITIONAL RESILIENCE AND FOOD SECURITY OF THE MOST VULNERABLE IN MALI/RENFORCER LA RÉSILIENCE NUTRITIONNELLE ET LA SÉCURITÉ ALIMEN Long: This project aims to strengthen the resilience of vulnerable communities, mainly women and girls, in the Mopti and Ségou regions of Mali. The project also aims to improve the food, nutrition, and health situation, increase agricultural productivity and incomes of target populations, while tackling the effects of climate change on food security in their communities.Project activities include: (1) rehabilitating health and drinking water infrastructure in health centers, schools, and households in targeted communities, (2) strengthening the prevention and management of malnutrition in children, and pregnant and lactating women, (3) distributing nutritious meals to students, (4) organizing village savings and credit associations, school gardens, and income-generating activities for small producers, particularly women, (5) creating and rehabilitating productive community assets (irrigated perimeter, reforestation of drylands, water collection systems, etc.), (6) working to ensure joint management of the natural resources shared between farmers and herders, and (7) building the capacity of women to make informed decisions in households and communities by providing leadership training and raising awareness of gender equality in communities.The project is jointly implemented by the World Food Programme (WFP), the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). / Ce projet vise à renforcer la résilience des communautés vulnérables, principalement des femmes et des filles, des zones ciblées des régions de Mopti et de Ségou, au Mali. Le projet vise également à améliorer la situation alimentaire, nutritionnelle et sanitaire, et à augmenter la productivité agricole et les revenus des populations ciblées, tout en s'attaquant aux effets des changements climatiques sur la sécurité alimentaire.Les activités du projet comprennent : 1) réhabiliter les infrastructures sanitaires et d'approvisionnement en eau potable dans les centres de santé, les écoles et les ménages des communautés ciblées, 2) renforcer la prévention et la prise en charge de la malnutrition chez les enfants et les femmes enceintes et allaitantes, 3) distribuer des repas nutritifs aux élèves, 4) mettre en place des associations villageoises d'épargne et de crédit, des champs-écoles et des activités génératrices de revenus pour les petits producteurs, particulièrement les femmes, 5) créer et réhabiliter les actifs communautaires productifs (périmètre irrigué, reforestation des terres arides, systèmes de collecte des eaux, etc.), 6) travailler à assurer une gestion conjointe des ressources naturelles partagées entre agriculteurs et éleveurs, 7) renforcer la capacité des femmes à prendre des décisions éclairées au sein des ménages et des communautés en leur fournissant de la formation en leadership et en sensibilisant les communautés à l'égalité des genres.Le projet est mis en œuvre conjointement par le Programme alimentaire mondial (PAM), l'Organisation des Nations Unies pour l'agriculture et l'alimentation (FAO) et le Fonds des Nations Unies pour l'enfance (UNICEF).

projecttitle: Food and Nutrition Security and Climate Change in the Sahel (SANC2S)/Sécurité Alimentaire et Nutritionnelle et Changements Climatiques au Sahel (SANC2S)
project_descrip: Short: FOOD AND NUTRITION SECURITY AND CLIMATE CHANGE IN THE SAHEL (SANC2S)/SÉCURITÉ ALIMENTAIRE ET NUTRITIONNELLE ET CHANGEMENTS CLIMATIQUES AU SAHEL (SANC Long: The Food and Nutrition Security and Climate Change in the Sahel (SANC2S) project will receive a maximum contribution of $ 13,300,000 over 5 years (2020-21 to 2024-25). It will be implemented by Development and Peace and its local partners to tackle malnutrition, food insecurity and poverty in communities in Niger, Mali and Burkina Faso. To do this, it will rely on the leadership of women and young people in the implementation of an innovative approach. This will link 1) strengthening the climate resilience of the agriculture, agroforestry, livestock and fisheries sectors through better management of shared natural resources and 2) strengthening of value, particularly beneficial for women and young people, in order to respond to inter-community and cross-border challenges. This initiative based on the environment-poverty-insecurity nexus is aligned with the Feminist International Assistance Policy as well as national and regional plans and policies for development and adaptation to climate change.By mobilizing and stabilizing young people in legal socio-economic activities sensitive to gender and resilient in the face of climate change, the project responds to a crucial issue of the development of local communities. This is a fundamental building block for transforming unequal gender-based systems and promoting peace in this troubled region. / Le projet Sécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle et changements climatiques au Sahel (SANC2S) bénéficiera d'une contribution maximale de 13 300 000$ sur 5 ans (2020-21 à 2024-25). Il sera mis en œuvre par Développement et Paix et ses partenaires locaux afin de s'attaquer à la malnutrition, l'insécurité alimentaire et la pauvreté de communautés du Niger, Mali et Burkina Faso. Pour ce faire, il s'appuiera sur le leadership des femmes et des jeunes dans la mise en œuvre d'une approche innovante. Celle-ci liera 1) le renforcement de la résilience face au climat des secteurs de l'agriculture, de l'agroforesterie, de l'élevage et des pêches grâce à une meilleure gestion des ressources naturelles partagées et 2) le renforcement des chaînes de valeur, particulièrement porteuses pour les femmes et les jeunes, afin de répondre aux enjeux intercommunautaires et transfrontaliers. Cette initiative basée sur le nexus environnement-pauvreté-insécurité est alignée sur la Politique d'aide internationale féministe de même que les plans et politiques nationales et régionales de développement et d'adaptation aux changements climatiques.Par la mobilisation et la stabilisation des jeunes dans des activités socio-économiques licites sensibles au genre et résilientes face aux changements climatiques, le projet répond à un enjeu crucial du développement des communautés locales. C'est une des composantes fondamentales d'une transformation des systèmes inégaux basés sur le genre et de la promotion de la paix dans cette région éprouvée.

projecttitle: Using Demand Side Management to Adapt to Water Scarcity and Climate Change in the Saiss Basin- Morocco
project_descrip: Short: USING DEMAND SIDE MANAGEMENT TO ADAPT TO WATER SCARCITY AND CLIMATE CHANGE IN THE SAISS BASIN- MOROCCO Long: The Saiss is a sub-basin of the Sebou basin in Northern Morocco. Due to decreased precipitation and increased water demand, the surface waters of the Saiss basin have been greatly reduced. At the current rate of exploitation, the aquifer will be depleted within 25 years. This project will examine whether demand-side management (DSM) can provide a solid basis for water management and strengthen the capacity for adapting to climate change in the Saiss basin. The project will work with multiple stakeholders and endeavor to benefit the most vulnerable and disadvantaged communities on the project sites. Since over 80% of the water consumed in the Saiss is used in agriculture, the project will focus on this sector. Researchers will test technical options for DSM in large-scale irrigation systems, demonstrate the value of DSM to smallholders through pilot projects, create two operational water-users associations supported by training and capacity building, and promote better policy making, enforcement and management on the part of local authorities and the relevant ministries.

projecttitle: Scaling up Quinoa Value Chain to Improve Food and Nutritional Security in the Rural/Poor Communities of Morocco
project_descrip: Short: SCALING UP QUINOA VALUE CHAIN TO IMPROVE FOOD AND NUTRITIONAL SECURITY IN THE RURAL/POOR COMMUNITIES OF MOROCCO Long: In Morocco rural poverty remains a challenge and is predicted to intensify. Water resources are becoming scarcer, a situation aggravated by the effects of climate change, erratic rainfall and a succession of drought years. Sustainability of irrigated agriculture is also threatened by salinization with approximately 30% of the soils in irrigated areas being salt-affected. In this context, introduction of crops with a high value and a high tolerance to stress would enable to address simultaneously two interrelated challenges: abiotic stresses that undermine crop production and poverty that impacts the rural poor. Quinoa is a revenue-generating crop which was introduced in Morocco in the 2000s as a drought and salinity-tolerant alternative crop. However, its production has been constrained by lack of access to well-adapted and high-yielding cultivars, inappropriate crop management practices, weak value chains and limited market demand.The overall goal of the proposed project is to improve food security and incomes of smallholder farmers in marginal areas of Morocco through the production, consumption and sale of high-value and stress-tolerant Quinoa. The project will be implemented in two phases over a period of three years. The pilot phase will target 200 smallholders in Rhamna province where a significant number of farmers live under the poverty threshold and where a Quinoa value chain already exists but is constrained by various factors. In this phase, the project will analyze the existing Quinoa value chain, and will develop and test a pro-poor business model for Quinoa production and marketing. It will introduce and disseminate Quinoa cultivars with high tolerance to abiotic stresses and high productivity and yield stability, as well as promote appropriate crop production/management practices among smallholder Quinoa growers. Linkages between farmers and other value chain actors will be established. The scaling up phase will have two components. The first will scale up the piloted business model in several rural communities of Rhamna province. At least 1,000 families will be targeted for a total of 5,000 people. The second component will focus on creating a favorable policy environment for scaling up Quinoa production and consumption across Morocco. The project fits within the framework of Morocco Green Plan, which supports smallholder agriculture in areas with fragile ecosystems, aiming at improving the incomes of the most vulnerable farmers. The Ministry of Agriculture has expressed interest to financially support the proposed project in its scaling up phase. ICBA (International Center for Biosaline Agriculture) has been the main institution behind the development of this project. The two co-recipients of IDRC's funding, in charge of the project implementation, are ICBA and Mohammed VI Polytechnic University.

projecttitle: User Driven Approaches to make Government and Farmer led Smallholder Irrigation in Mozambique more Productive (Cultiaf 2)
project_descrip: Short: USER DRIVEN APPROACHES TO MAKE GOVERNMENT AND FARMER LED SMALLHOLDER IRRIGATION IN MOZAMBIQUE MORE PRODUCTIVE (CULTIAF 2) Long: The Mozambique government and other development partners have invested significant efforts in revitalizing and expanding smallholder irrigation schemes to improve agricultural productivity, increase food security, reduce poverty, and increase resilience to climate variability. Their efforts are in addition to farmer-led irrigation schemes, estimated to be at least twice the size of government-funded smallholder irrigation schemes. Despite these investments, inefficiencies remain and constrain the performance of both schemes.This project aims to improve economic efficiency and institutional sustainability by identifying the challenges facing 12 government-funded smallholder and farmer-led irrigation schemes in the Gaza and Manica provinces of Mozambique. Once the challenges are identified, a combination of technical, social, and institutional innovations — such as best soil and water management practices, business plans and market linkages, and water user associations — will be launched with the goal of benefitting approximately 51,000 farmers. A comparative case study analysis of the changes in the management, productivity levels, and profitability levels for farmers within the 12 schemes will also be conducted. The project is expected to double the yields of selected crops, increase crop prices due to market linkages, expand production, and increase farmer incomes. By generating stronger evidence on how to design and effectively manage smallholder irrigation schemes, this project intends to inform the design of future irrigation schemes in the country.This project is funded through the second phase of the Cultivate Africa's Future Fund (CultiAF-2), a joint program of IDRC and the Australian International Food Security Research Centre of the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. CultiAF supports research to achieve long-term food security in eastern and southern Africa.

projecttitle: PROAGRI COMMON FUND - PROAGRI COMMON FUND 2004-2009
project_descrip: Short: PROAGRI COMMON FUND Long: PROJECT DESCRIPTION: THE NATIONAL PROGRAMME FOR AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT (PROAGRI) IS MOZAMBIQUE'S AGRICULTURAL SECTOR PUBLIC EXPENDITURE PROGRAM. PROAGRI HAS THREE IMMEDIATE OBJECTIVES: 1. TO TRANSFORM THE MINISTRY OF AGRICULTURE & RURAL DEVELOPMENT (MADER) INTO A MODERN INSTITUTION FOR PUBLIC SECTOR INTERVENTIONS IN SUPPORT OF THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR, 2. TO INCREASE AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION AND PRODUCTIVITY IN ORDER TO IMPROVE INCOME AND FOOD SECURITY FOR RURAL HOUSEHOLDS, AND 3. TO PROTECT, CONSERVE, DEVELOP AND ENSURE PUBLIC ACCESS TO NATURAL RESOURCES ON A SUSTAINABLE BASIS. THESE OBJECTIVES ARE ADDRESSED THROUGH EIGHT THEMATIC COMPONENTS: INSTITUTIONAL DEVELOPMENT, RESEARCH, EXTENSION, SUPPORT FOR CROP PRODUCTION, LIVESTOCK, FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, LAND MANAGEMENT, AND IRRIGATION. A COMMON FLOW OF FUNDS MECHANISM (CFFM) ALLOWS DONORS AND GOVERNMENT TO POOL THEIR FUNDING TO PROAGRI.EXPECTED IMPACT: 1. INCREASED AGRICULTURAL OUTPUT AND PRODUCTIVITY, ESPECIALLY AT THE HOUSEHOLD LEVEL. 2. INCREASED PROFITABILITY OF AGRICULTURAL ACTIVITY. 3. REDUCED FOOD INSECURITY.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: OUTCOMES FOR PROAGRI PHASE I (1999-2004): 1. MADER TRANSFORMED INTO A MODERN INSTITUTION FOR PUBLIC SECTOR INTERVENTIONS IN SUPPORT OF THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR, 2. AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION AND PRODUCTIVITY INCREASED IN ORDER TO IMPROVE INCOME AND FOOD SECURITY FOR RURAL HOUSEHOLDS, 3. PUBLIC ACCESS TO NATURAL RESOURCES PROTECTED, CONSERVED, DEVELOPED AND ENSURED ON A SUSTAINABLE BASIS.EXPECTED OUTPUTS: 1. CIDA'S ENTRY INTO PROAGRI CFFM. 2. CIDA FUNDING SUCCESSFULLY CHANNELED THROUGH THE PROAGRI CFFM. 3. TECHNICAL ADVICE AND ASSISTANCE PROVIDED BY CIDA, INCL. IN THE AREAS OF GENDER EQUALITY, ENVT AND HIV/AIDS AS CROSSCUTTING PRIORITIES. 4. CIDA INVOLVED IN PERIODIC SUPERVISION MISSIONS AND ANNUAL REVIEWS. 5. MONITORING REPORTS PRODUCED BY CIDA, OTHER DONORS OR MADER.GENDER EQUALITY MEASURES: EVALUATIONS HAVE SHOWN THAT PROAGRI I DID NOT ADEQUATELY INTEGRATE GE IN MADER PLANNING AND ACTIONS. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, CIDA WILL SEEK OPPORTUNITIES TO SUPPORT MADER IN THE FOLLOWING AREAS: 1. THE ONGOING INSTITUTIONAL REFORM AND MODERNIZATION OF MADER WILL HELP FOSTER GE MAINSTREAMING ACROSS MADER. 2. CIDA STRONGLY SUPPORTS THE ROLE OF THE GE UNIT WITHIN MADER. 3. THE ABILITY OF MADER'S GU TO EFFECTIVELY INTEGRATE THE DIFFERENT NEEDS AND EXPERIENCES OF WOMEN AND MEN AND GIRLS AND BOYS, INTO PROPOSED POLICIES, PROJECTS, PROGRAMS AND DECISION-MAKING PROCESSES IS CONSTRAINED DUE TO A LACK OF FINANCIAL AND HUMAN RESOURCES, AND LIMITED CAPACITY TO UNDERTAKE GENDER-BASED ANALYSIS OF SUCH INITIATIVES WITHIN MADER AS A WHOLE. 4. WHILE STRENGTHENING THE ROLE OF MADER GU TO BE ABLE TO EFFECTIVELY PROMOTE THE INTEGRATION OF GE ACROSS MADER, PROMOTING OWNERSHIP AND CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT BY ALL MADER DEPARTMENTS AND DIVISIONS TO BE ACCOUNTABLE FOR GE RESULTS IS INTEGRAL TO THE SUCCESSFULL MAINSTREAMING OF THE ISSUE. 5. BOTH VERTICAL PROGRAMMING ON GENDER-RELATED AGRICULTURE INITIATIVES, AND HORIZONTAL INTEGRATION OF GE IN OTHER TYPES OF AGRICULTURE INITIATIVES, WILL ENSURE A COMPREHENSIVE APPROACH TO ADDRESSING THE GENDER-RELATED IMPACTS OF AGRICULTURE. 6.
